snippet: The Senate’s findings on the government’s use of torture, set for release Tuesday, have spurred clashes over the risk that they will trigger a backlash overseas.
abstract: Obama administration and its Republican critics clash over wisdom and risk of making public a long-awaited Senate report on use of torture by United States government after September 2001 terrorist attacks; critics fear report could trigger backlash overseas; US diplomatic facilities and military bases are put on alert for heightened security risks; some Republicans warn that graphic accounts of torture used by CIA during George W Bush administration could incite violence.

byline.original: By MARK LANDLER and PETER BAKER
byline.contributor: Mark Landler reported from Washington, and Peter Baker from New York. Rick Lyman contributed reporting from Warsaw; Ben Hubbard from Beirut, Lebanon; and Jeffrey Gettleman from Nairobi, Kenya.

lead_paragraph: The Senate’s findings on the government’s use of torture, set for release Tuesday, have spurred clashes over the risk that they will trigger a backlash overseas.

headline.main: White House and Republicans Clash Over C.I.A. Torture Report
headline.print_headline: White House and G.O.P. Clash Over Torture Report
